MasterAnswered on 16 Mar 2019To have a better understanding of IPO, you can check out this article from investopedia: https://www.investopedia.com/terms/i/ipo.aspBasically, there are a few advantages for a company to IPO:The primary objective of an IPO is usually to raise funds for the company.The company can also have the choice to raise additional funds in the future by having a secondary offering.Merger and acquisitions becomes easier for the company as it can use its shares to acquire another company/firm.To publicize or make the company more well known.0 comments1

Richard Woon Tian JunLevel 6. MasterAnswered on 16 Mar 2019Generally to cement the value of the equity held by the stakeholders of the company - the IPO is seen as a way to put actual dollar value on their stake. If not, it would be purely according to the valuation of a acquiring company - which may not be a fair valuation. The market is seen as a more efficient and fairer platform of ensuring that you get your money's worth on the piece of pie you are currently holding onto, and if it comes to a point in time you wish to leave the company you can always liquidate relatively easily in the public exchange as compared to private equity negotiation and valuation.0 comments0

On the other hand, companies that are more established uses IPO to allow owners to exit some or all their ownership by selling shares to the public.0 comments0

Isaac Chan, Business  at NUSLevel 8. WizardAnswered on 14 Mar 2019There are several advantage that the company can take.One of the main advantages is that the company can raise more capital to expand it's business, which could include higher upfront capital expenditures or research and development. Another advantage is that companies can use stocks as a form of consideration when engaging in merges and acquisition. This can help open up M&A opportunities since the transaction does not need to be funded by cash. Owners of the company can also cash out and make their fortuen through their IPO, as well as provide employees with the chance to exercise their options and issue new ones.0 comments0
